isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - DRIVETRAIN FAILURE ANALYSIS - AXLE COMPONENTS - POWER DIVIDER

step1.para: Damaged teeth due to shock impact. One sudden shock impact fractured the engaged teeth of these two gears. The adjacent teeth were damaged by metal pieces ( Figure 53).

figure.caption: Figure 53. Damaged Teeth Due to Shock Impact

step1.para: Broken gear teeth from fatigue failure. A shock load to the gear teeth in mesh produced cracking of the case hardened tooth surface. Continued loading resulted in a progression of fractures as evidenced by beach marks ( Figure 54).

figure.caption: Figure 54. Broken Gear Teeth From Fatigue Failure

step1.para: Broken sliding clutch. An instantaneous shock load created the rough surface pattern on the fracture ( Figure 55). This can be caused by trying to engage the inter-axle differential lockout while the wheels are spinning.
Gear bushing scored. Contaminated lubricant with fine particles caused scoring. Some pitting and scoring has occurred on the gear thrust washer surface ( Figure 56).

Input shaft broken. Multiple shock loads produced the flat, rough break of this input shaft ( Figure 57). It can be caused by abusive truck operation, incorrect use of inter-axle differential lockout or abusive clutch operation.

Input shaft torsional fatigue failure. The shaft surface initially cracks from an extremely high load. The cracks progress to the center of the core under normal operation until the shaft fails ( Figure 58).

figure.caption: Figure 58. Input Shaft Torsional Fatigue Failure

step1.para: Output shaft torsional shock failure. This is the result of a shock load and can occur in a single impact ( Figure 59). The direction of spline twist will indicate whether the vehicle was moving forward or in reverse.

figure.caption: Figure 59. Output Shaft Torsional Shock Failure
